[DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY]
[Sec.] 16.04.010. - Short title. This title shall be known and may be cited as "the land subdivision regulations of the city of Grantville, Georgia." (Prior Code, § 16.04.010; Ord. No. 668, § SR1-1, 5-13-1996) [Sec.] 16.04.020. - Land subdivision—Scope of term. [The term] "land subdivision" includes all divisions of a tract or parcel of land into two or more lots, building sites, or other division for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of sale, legacy, or building development, and includes all division of land involving a new street or a change in existing streets, and includes resubdivision and, where appropriate to the context, relates to the process of subdividing or to the land or area subdivided; provided, however, that the following are not included within this definition: A. The combination of previously platted lots or the division of an existing lot between adjoining lots which are unaltered from the approved plat, where the total number of lots is reduced and the resultant lots are equal to the standards set forth in this title; B. The division of land into parcels of five acres or more where no new street is involved, provided lot depth does not exceed twice the width at the building line; C. The division of land in nonresidential zoning districts where no minimum lot size is specified and no new street is involved, provided lot depth does not exceed twice the width of the building line; D. A filing fee to cover the cost of investigation and review of the subdivision; the cost of filing the plat; and the cost of reproducing the necessary copies shall be charged to the subdivider according to the schedule posted in City Hall. (Prior Code, § 16.04.020; Ord. No. 694, 4-27-1998; Ord. No. 668, § SR1-2, 5-13-1996) [Sec.] 16.04.030. - Compliance with title prerequisite to approval of subdivision. No subdivision of land within the city that fails to meet the requirements of this title shall be approved by the Grantville planning commission, hereafter called the planning commission. (Prior Code, § 16.04.030; Ord. No. 668, § SR1-3, 5-13-1996) [Sec.] 16.04.040. - Transfer, sale of land in unapproved subdivision. The transfer of, sale of, agreement to sell, or negotiation to sell land by reference to or exhibition of, or other use of a plat of a subdivision that has not been given final approval under the terms of this chapter and recorded in the office of the clerk of the superior court of Coweta County shall be a misdemeanor, punishable, as provided by law; and the description by metes and bounds in the instrument of transfer or other document shall not exempt the transaction from such penalties. (Prior Code, § 16.04.040; Ord. No. 668, § SR1-4, 5-13-1996) [Sec.] 16.04.050. - Construction prohibited. A. Street Work. No public authority shall accept, lay out, improve, grade, pave, light or maintain any street nor lay [or] authorize the utilities or facilities in a street not shown on an approved and recorded final plat, unless such street has received the legal status of a public street. B. Building Construction. No building permit shall be issued for and no building or other structure shall be erected on any lot within the city unless: (1) the street giving access to such lot is a public street, as specified above; and (2) the lot, if created after the effective date of these regulations, is in conformity with the provisions of these regulations. Any building erected in violation of these provisions is an unlawful structure and the building official, city attorney, or other agent of the city shall enjoin such erection or cause the building to be vacated or removed. (Prior Code, § 16.04.050; Ord. No. 668, § SR1-5, 5-13-1996) [Sec.] 16.04.060. - Effect of conflict of provisions. Insofar as the provisions of this title are inconsistent with the provisions of any other ordinance, the provisions of this title shall be controlling. The requirements of, restrictions imposed and powers conferred by this title shall be in addition and supplemental to the requirements of, restrictions imposed and powers conferred by other ordinance. (Prior Code, § 16.04.060; Ord. No. 668, § SR1-6, 5-13-1996) [Sec.] 16.04.070. - Variances. Applications for variances from the provision of these regulations and appeals from decisions of the planning commission shall be heard by the board of zoning appeals under the terms of the zoning ordinance of the city of Grantville. (Prior Code, § 16.04.070; Ord. No. 668, § SR1-7, 5-13-1996) [Sec.] 16.04.080. - Usage. A. For the purpose of these regulations, certain numbers, abbreviations, terms, and words used in this chapter shall be used, interpreted, and defined, as set forth in this chapter. B. Unless the context clearly indicates to the contrary, words used in the present tense include the future tense; words used in the plural number include the singular; the word "herein" means "in these regulations;" the word "regulations" means "these regulations." C. A "person" includes a corporation, a partnership, and an incorporated association of persons such as a club; "shall" is always mandatory; a "building" includes a "structure;" a "building" or "structure" includes any part thereof; "used" or "occupied," as applied to any land or building, shall be construed to include the words "intended, arranged, or designed to be used or occupied." (Prior Code, § 16.04.080; Ord. No. 668, § SR4-1, 5-13-1996) [Sec.] 16.04.090. - Words and terms defined. [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this appendix, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] "Alley" means a public or private right-of-way primarily designed to serve as secondary access to the side or rear of those properties whose principal frontage is on some other street. "Block" means a tract of land bounded by streets, or by a combination of streets and public parks, cemeteries, railroad rights-of-way, shorelines of waterways, or boundary lines of municipalities. "Bond" means a cash deposit, escrow account, maintenance or performance bond, or other legally binding instrument of financial security acceptable to the city, to assure the completion of reconstruction of the improvements covered by such instrument. Said financial security shall be in the amount of at least one hundred twenty (120) percent of the estimated cost of completing or reconstructing those improvements (as determined by the city manager). "Building" means any structure intended for support, shelter, or enclosure of persons, animals, or property of any kind, including a structure which has no enclosing walls. The term "building" shall be interpreted as if followed by the words "or part thereof." (For the purposes of these regulations, each portion of a building separated from other portions by a fire wall shall be considered as a separate building.) "Building line" means a line established at the minimum allowable distance between the nearest portion of any building (excluding the outermost three feet of any uncovered porches, steps, gutters, and similar fixtures) and the centerline of the street or the right-of-way line, as required by zoning district regulations. "Cul-de-sac" means a local street with only one outlet and having an appropriate terminal for the safe and convenient reversal of traffic movement. "Easement" means authorization by a property owner for the use by another, and for a specified purpose, of any designated part of his property. "Frontage" means that side of a lot abutting on a street or way and ordinarily regarded as the front of the lot, but it shall not be considered as the ordinary side of a corner lot. "Grade" means the slope of a street or other public way, being the change in elevation of the street surface per one hundred (100) feet of horizontal distance along the centerline, expressed as a percent. "Improvement, Public." [The term] "public improvement" means any street, sidewalk, pedestrian way, drainage structure, or other facility for which the city may ultimately assume the responsibility for maintenance and operation, or which may affect an improvement for which city responsibility is established. "Lot" means a tract, plot, or portion of a subdivision or other parcel of land intended as a unit for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of transfer of ownership or for building development; also, a portion of land devoted to a common use or occupied by a building or group of buildings devoted to a common use, together with the customary accessories and open spaces belonging to the same. "Lot, Corner." [The term] "corner lot" means a lot situated at the intersection of two streets, the interior angle of such intersection not exceeding one hundred thirty-five (135) degrees. "Master plan" means a comprehensive plan for development of the city, adopted by the city council, and including any part of such plan separately adopted and any amendment to such plan, or parts thereof. "Official map" means the map established in conjunction with the master plan by the city council showing the locations of streets, street rights-of-way, and drainage facilities to be improved, reconstructed, realigned, widened, or acquired; and parks and other public lands and facilities to be acquired. "Parkway" means a major street: (1) with a landscaped median dividing opposing traffic lanes; (2) providing no access to abutting land; (3) having median openings (crossovers) not closer together than nine hundred (900) feet, center to center; and (4) having a median and rights-of-way of low-maintenance design, densely planted with trees and shrubs acceptable to the city. "Registered land surveyor" means a land surveyor properly licensed and registered in the state. "Resubdivision" means a change in a map of an approved or recorded subdivision plat if such change affects any street layout on such map or area reserved thereon for public use, or any lot line; or if it affects any map or plan legally recorded prior to the adoption of any regulations controlling subdivisions. "Screening" means either: (1) a strip of at least ten (10) feet wide, densely planted (or having equivalent natural growth) with shrubs or trees at least four feet high at the time of planting, of a type that will form a year-round dense screen at least six feet high; or (2) an opaque wall or barrier or uniformly painted fence at least six feet high. "Street, Arterial." [The term] "arterial street" means a street intended to serve major movements of traffic within or through the city, interconnecting the principal traffic generators within the city and the important rural routes; providing access to land as a secondary function, with controls on parking and driveway access to improve capacity. "Street, Collector." [The term] "collector street" means a street intended to serve the internal traffic movement within an area of the city, such as a neighborhood or large subdivision, moving traffic from local streets to arterial streets [and] intended to supply abutting property with the same degree of land service as a local street, while at the same time serving area traffic movement. "Street, Local." [The term] "local street" means a street intended solely to provide access to immediately adjacent land. "Street, Major." [The term] "major street" means as designated on the zoning map or the official map: an arterial street, or a collector street serving a large area or high-traffic-generating land uses; also, a proposed street intended to serve the function of an arterial street or a high-traffic-volume collector street. "Street, Minor." [The term] "minor street" means a local street; or a collector street with a low traffic level, providing one of several alternative outlets from an area to the major street system; also, a proposed street intended to serve the function of a local street or a low-traffic volume collector street. "Street right-of-way width" means the distance between property lines measured at right angles to the centerline of the street. "Subdivider" means any person who: (1) having an interest in land, causes it, directly or indirectly, to be divided into a subdivision; or who (2) directly or indirectly, sells, leases, or develops, or offers to sell, lease, or develop, or advertises for sale, lease, or development, any interest, lot, parcel, site, unit, or plat in a subdivision, or who (3) engages directly or through an agent in the business of selling, leasing, developing, or offering for sale, lease, or development a subdivision or any interest, lot, parcel, site, unit, or plat in a subdivision, and who (4) is directly or indirectly controlled by or in direct or indirect common control with any of the foregoing. "Subdivision, Major." [The term] "major subdivision" means any subdivision not classified as a minor subdivision. "Subdivision, Minor." [The term] "minor subdivision" means any subdivision containing not more than four lots fronting on an existing public street, not involving any new street or the extension of municipal facilities or the creation of any public improvements, not adversely affecting future subdivision of the remainder of the parcel or adjoining property, and not in conflict with any provision or portion of the master plan, official map, zoning ordinance, or these regulations; except that a phase of a larger subdivision under development may not be treated as a minor subdivision. "Subdivision, Nonresidential." [The term] "nonresidential subdivision" means a subdivision whose intended use is other than residential, such as commercial or industrial. (Prior Code, § 16.04.090; Ord. No. 668, § SR4-2, 5-13-1996) DIVISION 2. - PLATS
[Sec.] 16.08.010. - Preapplication review of proposed subdivision. A. Duty of Subdivider. Whenever the subdivision of a tract of land within the city is proposed, the subdivider or his agent shall consult early and informally with the secretary of the planning commission. The subdivider may submit sketch plans and data showing existing conditions within the site and its vicinity and the proposed layout and development of the subdivision. B. Purpose of Review. The purpose of the preapplication review is to facilitate the subsequent preparation of plans. C. Fees. No fees shall be charged for a preapplication review. (Prior Code, § 16.08.010; Ord. No. 668, § SR 2-1, 5-13-1996) [Sec.] 16.08.020. - Application for preliminary plat approval. A. A preliminary plat shall not be required for a minor subdivision. The subdivider may apply directly for final plat approval. B. For a major subdivision, following the preapplication review, the subdivider or his agent shall submit to the secretary of the planning commission: 1. A letter requesting review and approval of a preliminary plat and giving the name and address of the person to whom the notice of the hearing by the planning commission on the preliminary plat shall be sent. 2. The preliminary plat and other documents, as specified in Section 16.08.040. 3. A preliminary plat filing fee of fifty cents per lot, fifteen dollars ($15.00) minimum if the plat contains less than thirty (30) lots. (Prior Code, § 16.08.020; Ord. No. 668, § SR 2-2, 5-13-1996) [Sec.] 16.08.030. - Review of preliminary plat. A. Report, Hearing Required. The secretary of the planning commission shall check the plat submitted pursuant to Section 16.08.020 for conformance to the rules and regulations of this chapter and report his findings and recommendations to the planning commission, which shall afford a hearing on the preliminary plat, notice of the time and place of which shall be given by the secretary of the planning commission to the persons designated in the letter requesting preliminary plat review and approval, not less than five days prior to the date of the hearing. B. Action by Planning Commission. Thereafter, the planning commission shall give tentative approval or disapproval to the preliminary plat, including a statement of the reasons therefor if the preliminary plat is disapproved. One copy shall be returned to the subdivider or his agent and one copy added to the records of the planning commission. C. Effect, Duration of Approval. Tentative approval of a preliminary plat does not constitute approval of a final plat. It indicates only approval of the layout as a guide to the preparation of the final plat. Tentative approval shall expire and be null and void after a period of one year unless an extension of time is approved by the planning commission. D. Failure of Planning Commission to Act. If action on a preliminary plat is not taken by the planning commission within thirty (30) days of the date of submittal, the preliminary plat shall be considered approved and a certificate of approval shall be issued on demand. However, the applicant for approval may waive this requirement and consent to an extension of time. (Prior Code, § 16.08.030; Ord. No. 668, § SR 2-3, 5-13-1996) [Sec.] 16.08.040. - Preliminary plat specifications. A. Scale. The preliminary plat shall be clearly and legibly drawn at a scale of not more than one hundred (100) feet to one inch. B. Sheet Size. Sheet size shall be eighteen (18) inches by twenty-four (24) inches. If the complete plat cannot be shown on one sheet of this size, it may be shown on more than one sheet with an index map on a separate sheet of the same size. C. Ground Elevations. The preliminary plat shall show ground elevations by contours at intervals of not more than two feet, based on a datum plane approved by the building department of the city. If any part of the land platted lies within a flood hazard district, as defined by the zoning ordinance of the city, elevations shall be referenced to the National Geodetic Vertical Datum of 1929 and the boundaries of that district shall be drawn on the plat. Ground elevation contours shall not be required for minor subdivisions, provided that: (1) no part of the land lies within a flood hazard district; and (2) the lots are small enough or the topography so little varied that suitability of the lots as building sites can be determined readily by visual inspection. D. Information to be Provided on Preliminary Plat. The preliminary plat shall contain the following information: 1. Name and address of owner of record and of subdivider; 2. Proposed name of subdivision; 3. North point, graphic scale and date; 4. Vicinity map showing location and acreage of the subdivision; 5. Exact boundary lines of the tract by lengths and bearings; 6. Names of owners of record of adjoining land; 7. Existing streets and utilities on and adjacent to the tract; 8. Proposed layout, including streets and alleys with proposed street names, right-of-way and pavement widths, lot lines with approximate dimensions, easements, land to be reserved or dedicated for public uses, and any land to be used for purposes other than single-family dwellings; 9. Locations of existing and proposed water supply, sanitary sewerage, and storm drainage lines and structures; 10. Such street cross-sections and centerline profiles as may be required by the secretary of the planning commission. E. Certificate of Tentative Approval. A certificate of tentative approval of the preliminary plat by the planning commission shall be inscribed on the plat as follows:
(Prior Code, § 16.08.040; Ord. No. 668, § SR 2-4, 5-13-1996) [Sec.] 16.08.050. - Application for final plat approval. After the preliminary plat of a proposed land subdivision has been given tentative approval by the planning commission, the subdivider or his agent shall submit to the secretary of the planning commission: A. A letter requesting review and approval of the final plat and giving the name and address of the person to whom the notice of the hearing by the planning commission on the final plat shall be sent. B. The final plat and other documents, as specified in Section 16.08.080. C. A final plat filing fee of ten dollars ($10.00). (Prior Code, § 16.08.050; Ord. No. 668, § SR 2-5, 5-13-1996) [Sec.] 16.08.060. - Review of final plat. A. Report, Hearing Required. The secretary of the planning commission shall check the final plat submitted pursuant to Section 16.08.050 for conformance with the tentatively approved preliminary plat and with the rules and regulations of this title, and report his findings and recommendations to the planning commission, which shall afford a hearing on the final plat, notice of the time and place of which shall be given by the secretary of the planning commission to the person designated in the letter requesting final plat review and approval, not less than five days prior to the date of the hearing. B. Action by Planning Commission. Thereafter, the planning commission shall approve or disapprove the final plat. A notation of the action shall be made on the original and two prints of the final plat, including a statement of the reasons therefor if the final plat is disapproved. If action on a final plat is not taken by the planning commission within thirty (30) days of the date of the submittal, the final plat shall be considered approved and a certificate of approval shall be issued on demand. However, the applicant for approval may waive this requirement and consent to an extension of time. (Prior Code, § 16.08.060; Ord. No. 668, § SR 2-6, 5-13-1996) [Sec.] 16.08.070. - Recording of final plat. A. Required. Upon approval of a final plat, the secretary of the planning commission shall have the final plat recorded in the office of the clerk of the superior court of Coweta County. The subdivider or his agent shall be responsible for the payment of the recording fee. B. Duty Upon Recordation. Upon recording of the approved final plat, the original drawing or a reproducible copy on drafting film of the final plat with all certificates endorsed thereon shall be provided by the subdivider for the records of the planning commission. (Prior Code, § 16.08.070; Ord. No. 668, § SR 2-7, 5-13-1996) DIVISION 3. - MINIMUM REQUIREMENTS AND DESIGN STANDARDS
[Sec.] 16.12.010. - Suitability of land. Land subject to flooding, improper drainage, or erosion that is for topographical or other reasons unsuitable for residential use shall not be platted for residential use nor for any other use that will continue or increase the danger to health, safety, or property, unless the hazards can be and are corrected. (Prior Code, § 16.12.010; Ord. No. 668, § SR3-1, 5-13-1996) [Sec.] 16.12.020. - Access. A. Access to every subdivision shall be provided over a publicly dedicated street. B. Where access to a proposed subdivision or to any lot therein is from a street under the jurisdiction of the Georgia Department of Transportation, such access must meet all requirements of that agency. (Prior Code, § 16.12.020; Ord. No. 668, § SR3-2, 5-13-1996) [Sec.] 16.12.030. - Conformance to master plan. A. Required. All streets and other features of the master plan of the city shall be platted by the subdivider in the location and to the dimensions indicated on the master plan. B. Reservations. When features of the master plan other than streets, such as schools or other public building sites, parks, or other land for public uses, are located in whole or in part in a land subdivision, such features shall be reserved by the subdivider for acquisition by the appropriate public agency. C. Land Not Required or Suitable. Whenever a plat proposes the dedication of land to public use that the planning commission finds [is] not required or [is not] suitable for such public use, the planning commission shall refuse to approve the plat. (Prior Code, § 16.12.030; Ord. No. 668, § SR3-3, 5-13-1996) [Sec.] 16.12.040. - Large-scale developments. The requirements of this title may be modified in the case of a large-scale community neighborhood unit, such as a housing project which is not subdivided into customary lots, blocks and streets, if the development is approved by the planning commission and if deed covenants or other legal measures to assure the accomplishment and continuance of the plan are provided. (Prior Code, § 16.12.040; Ord. No. 668, § SR3-4, 5-13-1996) [Sec.] 16.12.050. - General requirements for streets. A. Existing Streets. Existing streets shall be continued at the same or greater width, but in no case less than the required width. B. Street Names. Street names shall require the approval of the planning commission. Streets that are obviously in alignment with streets already existing and named shall be given the name of the existing street. Names of new streets shall not duplicate or closely approximate those of existing streets. C. Street Jogs. Street jogs with centerline offsets of less than one hundred twenty-five (125) feet shall not be permitted. D. Dead-End Streets. Except where topographic or other conditions make a greater length unavoidable, a dead-end street shall not be greater in length than five hundred (500) feet. 1. Permanent (cul-de-sac). A permanent dead-end street shall be provided at the closed end with a turnaround having a property line radius of at least fifty (50) feet with an outside pavement radius (not including curb and gutter) of at least forty (40) feet. It may not subsequently be extended through a platted subdivision lot originally served by it in order to serve land adjoining that lot. 2. Temporary. A temporary dead-end street shall terminate at the boundary of a subdivision or of a phase of the subdivision approved by the planning commission. A temporary T- or L-shaped turnaround shall be provided, and land outside the normal right-of-way used for such turnaround shall revert to abutters whenever the street is continued. E. Alleys. Alleys may be required at the rear of all lots used for multi-purpose, commercial or industrial developments, but shall not be provided in residential developments, unless the subdivider provides evidence satisfactory to the planning commission of the need for alleys. F. Adjoining Property. Unless an adjoining property owner agrees in writing, no new street may be so located that the back-of-curb is within twenty (20) feet of the property of such adjoining owner; except that this requirement shall not apply where: (1) such placement alone would render property on the opposite side of the street from such adjoining owner too shallow to meet minimum requirements of these regulations or the zoning ordinance; or (2) the remaining land is not wide enough to accommodate the required street or right-of-way. (Prior Code, § 16.12.050; Ord. No. 668, § SR3-5, 5-13-1996) [Sec.] 16.12.060. - Street design requirements. A. Street Right-of-Way Widths. Street right-of-way widths shall be as follows: 1. Major street in a residential area, sixty (60) feet; major collector street in a nonresidential area, sixty (60) feet; an arterial street, eighty-five (85) feet or as designated in the master plan; and a parkway, one hundred twenty (120) feet or as designated in the master plan; 2. Minor street intended to serve exclusively residential uses and which will serve as an outlet to the major street system for not more than forty (40) dwelling units, fifty (50) feet; 3. Alley, twenty (20) feet; 4. Any other street, sixty (60) feet. B. Street Pavement Widths. Street pavement widths (not including curbs and gutters) shall be as follows: 1. Major street in a residential area, thirty-six (36) feet; major collector street in a nonresidential area, thirty-six (36) feet; an arterial street, sixty (60) feet or as designated in the master plan; and a parkway, twenty-four (24) feet in each direction. 2. Minor street intended to serve exclusively residential uses and which will serve as an outlet to the major street system for not more than forty (40) dwelling units, twenty-four (24) feet; other minor street in a residential area, including a minor collector street, thirty-two (32) feet. 3. Alley, sixteen (16) feet. 4. Any other street, thirty-six (36) feet. C. Street Grades. Maximum and minimum street grades shall be as follows: 1. Major streets, not in excess of seven percent. 2. Minor streets, not more than two blocks long, and dead-end streets and alleys, fifteen (15) percent. 3. All other streets ten (10) percent. 4. No street grade shall be less than one half of one percent. D. Horizontal curvature. The minimum radii of centerline curvature shall be as follows: 1. Major streets as indicated in the master plan, but in no case less than eight hundred (800) feet. 2. Minor streets not more than two blocks long and dead-end streets and alleys, one hundred (100) feet. 3. All other streets, two hundred (200) feet. E. Tangents. Between reverse curves, there shall be a tangent having a length not less than the following: 1. Major streets, two hundred (200) feet. 2. Minor streets not more than two blocks long and dead-end streets and alleys, fifty (50) feet. 3. All other streets, one hundred (100) feet. F. Vertical Alignment. Street profile grades shall, connected by vertical curves of a minimum length equivalent to the following, times the algebraic difference between the rates of grade, expressed in feet per hundred: 1. Major streets, twenty (20) times. 2. All other streets and alleys, ten (10) times. G. Street Intersections. Street intersections shall be as nearly at right angles as possible. No street intersections shall be at an angle of less than sixty (60) degrees. H. Curbline Radius. The curbline radius at street intersections shall be at least fifteen (15) feet. Where the angle of street intersection is less than ninety (90) degrees, a longer radius may be required. I. Median Widths. Median widths between opposing traffic lanes (including curbs and gutters) shall be as follows: 1. Parkways, forty-six (46) feet. 2. All other streets, as designated in the master plan. (Prior Code, § 16.12.060; Ord. No. 668, § SR3-6, 5-13-1996) [Sec.] 16.12.070. - Block requirements. Block lengths and widths shall be as follows: A. Length. Blocks shall be not greater than eighteen hundred (1,800) feet nor less than six hundred (600) feet in length. B. Width. Blocks shall be wide enough to provide two tiers of lots of minimum depth, except where fronting on major streets, limited access highways or railroads, or where other situations make this requirement impracticable. (Prior Code, § 16.12.070; Ord. No. 668, § SR3-7, 5-13-1996) [Sec.] 16.12.080. - Lot requirements. A. Conventional Lots. 1. [Lot widths.] Residential lots shall be not less than seventy-five (75) feet wide at the building line or as required by the zoning ordinance. They shall have a depth of not less than one hundred (100) feet. Lot size for nonresidential lots shall be as required by the zoning ordinance. Lots shall have a depth not greater than two times the width of the lot at the building line. 2. Lot Lines. All lot lines shall be perpendicular or radial to street lines. Dimensions of corner lots shall be large enough to allow for the additional side yard width adjoining the street. 3. Lots Abutting Public Streets. Each lot shall abut upon a dedicated public street. B. Townhouse or Attached-Dwelling Lots. 1. Lot Size. The lot size for each dwelling unit shall be as required by the zoning ordinance. 2. Lot Lines. Lot lines between attached dwelling units shall be extended in a straight line, perpendicular to the front face of the building, to the intersecting street right-of-way line. These lot lines shall also be perpendicular to street lines or, where the street line is curved, shall be as nearly radial to the street line as possible. Other lot lines shall be perpendicular to building walls for a distance of at least ten (10) feet from said walls but thereafter may be angled as desired. 3. Lots Abutting Public Streets. Each lot shall abut upon a dedicated public street. 4. Common Areas. Parking lots, driveways, and other areas which must be used by several lot owners and any additional areas not included in individual lots shall be owned in common by said lot owners, and such areas shall be maintained by the tenants-in-common. C. Resubdivision After Sale of Lots. Resubdivision to reduce lot size in all or part of a subdivision shall not be permitted where such an increase in density would adversely affect lots already sold; nor shall lot size in later phases of a subdivision be less than in previous phases, where such an increase in density would adversely affect lots already sold in previous phases. (Prior Code, § 16.12.080; Ord. No. 668, § SR3-8, 5-13-1996) [Sec.] 16.12.090. - Development along a major street. Where a subdivision abuts or contains a major street, the planning commission may require that access to such street be limited by one of the following means: A. The subdivision of lots so as to back onto the major street and front onto a parallel local street; no access being provided from the major street; and screening being provided in a strip of land along the rear property line of such lots. B. A series of cul-de-sacs, U-shaped streets, or short loops entered from and designed generally at right angles to such a parallel street, with the rear lines of their terminal lots backing onto the major street. C. A marginal access or service road, separated from the major street by a planting strip and having access thereto at suitable points. D. Where a minor street intersects the major street, corner lots of such dimensions that the front of the lot will be on the minor street. (Prior Code, § 16.12.090; Ord. No. 668, § SR3-9, 5-13-1996) [Sec.] 16.12.100. - Reserve strips. Reserve strips controlling access to streets, alleys, and public grounds shall not be permitted unless their control is placed in the hands of the city council, under conditions approved by the planning commission. (Prior Code, § 16.12.100; Ord. No. 668, § SR3-10, 5-13-1996) [Sec.] 16.12.110. - Easements. A. Utility Lines. Easements having a minimum width of ten (10) feet and located along the side or rear lot lines shall be provided as required for utility lines. B. Drainage. Where a subdivision is traversed by a sanitary sewer or piped storm sewer, there shall be provided a public maintenance easement of adequate width. C. Public Service Access. In townhouse and attached-dwelling subdivisions, easements contiguous with common areas and such other easements as are determined to be necessary by the city shall be provided to assure access to each lot for provision of public services and other services provided by franchise from the city. (Prior Code, § 16.12.110; Ord. No. 668, § SR3-11, 5-13-1996) [Sec.] 16.12.115. - Sidewalks. In each new subdivision that requires the construction of new streets, sidewalks must also be installed. The sidewalks must meet the construction standards set forth in the Coweta County regulations for subdivision sidewalks. The developer will be responsible for the construction of the installation of the sidewalks. (Prior Code, § 16.12.115; Ord. No. 725, 1-26-2004) [Sec.] 16.12.120. - Improvements required. A. Required. Every subdivider shall be required to install or to have installed by the appropriate agency at his expense the following street improvements and utilities: 1. Except where waived on major or limited access streets by provisions of this or other ordinances, provide street grading, curbs and gutters, and street paving; provided that on a parkway, curb and gutter may be waived adjacent to the median or on the outside edges of the pavement or both, where hydrologic analysis indicates that the design storm specified by the city will be absorbed in the median or in rights-of-way outside the pavement without erosion damage or harm to landscaping, aesthetics, or the public health or safety. 2. Provide water lines and fire hydrants, sanitary sewer lines and manholes, sidewalks (when determined by the planning commission to be essential for the safety of pedestrians), and monuments and markers. 3. Provide storm drainage facilities, including catchbasins, junction boxes, and storm sewer lines discharging directly into existing storm sewers or continuous streams. (Discharge to overland flow, artificial channels, or intermittent streams—normally flowing only in direct response to precipitation—is not permitted.) Where no such discharge points for a particular drainage basin exist within the boundary of the property to be developed, discharge to intermittent streams may occur at or within ten (10) feet of such boundary. Where necessary because of inadequate capacity in existing facilities, erosion problems, or adverse impact on adjoining property, detention structures or energy-dissipation structures shall be provided. 4. On townhouse and attached-dwelling lots, provide for underground service for electric power, telephones, cable television and similar services. No overhead service will be permitted. B. Standards. The foregoing street improvements, utilities and monuments shall be built to the standards specified by the agency responsible for each. C. Completion. The city council's certificate necessary for final plat approval shall not be granted until: 1. All improvements required in subsection A have been completed; or 2. All improvements required in subsections A.2 and A.3 of this section and all street grading, curbs and gutters, and street base have been completed; and 3. A bond has been deposited with the city clerk for any required improvements not yet completed or for any necessary minor repairs or minor changes to improvements already in place. All improvements must be completed within nine months after approval of the final plat. Upon final acceptance of all improvements, funds in such deposit or account shall be returned to the depositor. D. Public Improvements Bond. Where improvements constructed by a private developer are to be dedicated to the public, the developer shall, upon completion of construction, provide a bond to assure the structural durability, stability, and integrity of the improvements for one year from the date of acceptance by the city. Upon determination after one year that durability, stability, and integrity requirements have been met, the bond shall be released or returned to the depositor. As an alternative to providing a bond for one year, the developer may submit documentation by an engineering testing firm acceptable to the city, certifying that subgrade conditions, construction, and materials meet the city's standards. The certification shall be based on the level of testing specified by the city. (Prior Code, § 16.12.120; Ord. No. 668, § SR3-12, 5-13-1996) Sec. 16.12.130. - Monuments. The subdivider shall place permanent reference monuments in the subdivision, as required in this chapter and as approved by a registered land surveyor. Except as noted below, monuments shall be of stone or concrete, not less than thirty (30) inches in length, not less than four inches square or five inches in diameter, and marked on top with a cross, brass plug, iron rod, or other durable material securely embedded; or by iron rods or pipes at least thirty (30) inches long and two inches in diameter. Monuments shall be set flush with the ground and planted in such a manner that they will not be removed by frost. Monuments shall be properly set in the ground and approved by a registered land surveyor prior to the time the planning commission recommends approval of the final plat. A. Street Rights-of-Way. Monuments shall be located on street right-of-way lines at street intersections and at each end of all curves. They shall be spaced so as to be within sight of each other, the sight lines being contained wholly within the street limits. B. External Boundaries. The external boundaries of a subdivision shall be monumented. These monuments shall be placed at all corners, at each end of all curves, at the point where a curve changes its radius, at all angle points in any line, and at all angle points along the meander line, such points to be not less than twenty (20) feet back from the bank of any stream, except that when such corners or points fall within a street, or proposed future street, the monuments shall be placed in the side line of the street. C. Internal Boundaries. All internal boundaries and those corners and points not referred to in subsection B of this section shall be monumented in the field by iron pipes at least seven-eighths inch in diameter or by iron bars at least one-half inch in diameter. These monuments shall be placed at all lot corners, at each end of all curves, at a point where a curve changes its radius, and at all angle points in any line. D. Lines Extending to Streams. The lines of lots that extend to streams shall be monumented in the field by iron pipes at least seven-eights inch in diameter or by iron bars at least one-half inch in diameter. These monuments shall be placed at the point of intersection of the stream lot line, with a meander line established not less than twenty (20) feet back from the bank of the stream. (Prior Code, § 16.12.130; Ord. No. 668, § SR3-13, 5-13-1996) Sec. 16.12.140. - Addressing and building numbers. A. Street addressing. Prior to final plat approval, street numbers shall be submitted by the subdivider and, if appropriate, approved by the engineer or his designee. A number shall be assigned to all primary buildings and structures according to the following standards: 1. For corner lots, or those lots having multiple street frontages, an address shall be assigned for each street meeting the minimum required street frontage. The person who constructs a building or structure on a corner lot shall designate a street number on the building permit from among the numbers assigned on the final plat. All other permits issued for the corner lot shall identify this number as the street address. 2. The driveway and mailbox shall be located onto the street assigned the number on the final plat. If in the opinion of the director the driveway leading to the building or structure is moved to the extent that the number no longer corresponds to the street number provided on the final plat, the final plat must be modified. No inspection shall be made under these circumstances and no certificate of occupancy shall be issued until the final plat is modified. B. Building numbering. 1. Assigning numbers. Street numbers for the addressing system shall be assigned for all buildings and structures. Numbers must be erected and displayed in front of the project on a board with permanent numbers not smaller than two inches. Numbers must be in place at the beginning of the job before the footing inspection is made and must correspond to the address provided on building permit. The number shall be continuously displayed thereafter until the job is complete and all final inspections have been made. No inspection will be made where street numbers are not in place as required above. 2. Designation of street numbers. Street numbers for dwelling units and places of business on all public streets and street numbers or building numbers for dwelling units and places of business within apartment projects and nonresidential developments located on private streets shall be assigned by the City Clerk or designee in accordance with administrative procedures. 3. Posting. a. Each one-family and two-family dwelling unit constructed after January 1, 2014, shall have posted and maintained in a conspicuous place on the property, visible from the street providing general public access, the address of such dwelling unit in figures at least three inches high on a contrasting background. b. Each one-family and two-family dwelling unit constructed prior to January 1, 2014, shall have posted and maintained in a conspicuous place on the property, visible from the street providing general public access, the address of such dwelling unit in figures at least three inches high on a contrasting background. c. Each multifamily (three or more dwelling units) building shall have posted and maintained in a conspicuous place on the building, visible from the parking lot or street providing general public access, the address(es) or number(s) of the building in figures at least six inches high on a contrasting background and each individual apartment/unit within the building shall be marked on or about its main entrance with the individual apartment/unit number and/or address in figures at least three inches high on a contrasting background. In addition to the above, where a multifamily building has more than one exterior entrance, each such entrance shall be marked, in figures at least three inches high on contrasting background, with the numbers and/or address of each and every individual apartment/unit to which access is provided through that common entrance. This shall be effective on all new and existing units January 1, 2014. d. Each place of business and other non-residential occupied buildings shall have posted and maintained in a conspicuous place on the property, visible from the street providing general public access, the address of the place in figures at least three inches high on a contrasting background. When a building utilizes multiple addresses, such as multiple occupant mercantile buildings, the address range shall be posted. This shall be effective on all new and existing places of business January 1, 2014. ( Ord.
